Week 7 Discussion Notes

Midterm

I'm just gonna do two problems that I thought were relatively interesting.

Problem 2

Use induction to prove that 2n≤(n+1)!2^n \leq \p{n+1}!2n≤(n+1)! for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0.

Solution.

Base case: (n=0n = 0n=0)

When n=0n = 0n=0, we get 20=1=1!2^0 = 1 = 1!20=1=1!, so the base case holds.

Inductive step:

Suppose 2n≤(n+1)!2^n \leq \p{n+1}!2n≤(n+1)!. We want to show that 2n+1≤(n+2)!2^{n+1} \leq \p{n+2}!2n+1≤(n+2)! also. First, notice that since n≥0n \geq 0n≥0, we get n+2≥2n + 2 \geq 2n+2≥2. Thus,

2n+1=2⋅2n≤(n+2)⋅(n+1)!=(n+2)!.2^{n+1} = 2 \cdot 2^n \leq \p{n+2} \cdot \p{n+1}! = \p{n+2}!.2n+1=2⋅2n≤(n+2)⋅(n+1)!=(n+2)!.

By induction, the inequality holds for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0.

Problem 4

Let {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ be a recursive sequence such that s0=12s_0 = \frac{1}{2}s0​=21​ and sn+1=sn3s_{n+1} = s_n^3sn+1​=sn3​ for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0.

  1. Prove that sn∈[0,1]s_n \in \br{0, 1}sn​∈[0,1] for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0.
  2. Prove that sns_nsn​ is decreasing.
  3. Prove that sns_nsn​ is convergent and lim⁡n→∞sn=0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = 0n→∞lim​sn​=0.
Solution.

  1. We'll do this by induction.

    Base case: (n=0n = 0n=0)

    By definition, s0=12∈[0,1]s_0 = \frac{1}{2} \in \br{0, 1}s0​=21​∈[0,1] already, so the base case holds.

    Inductive step:

    Suppose that sn∈[0,1]s_n \in \br{0, 1}sn​∈[0,1], or equivalently, that 0≤sn≤10 \leq s_n \leq 10≤sn​≤1. Then by cubing everything, we get

    03≤sn3≤13  ⟹  0≤sn+1≤1,0^3 \leq s_n^3 \leq 1^3 \implies 0 \leq s_{n+1} \leq 1,03≤sn3​≤13⟹0≤sn+1​≤1,

    since sn+1=sn3s_{n+1} = s_n^3sn+1​=sn3​ by definition. Thus, by induction, sn∈[0,1]s_n \in \br{0, 1}sn​∈[0,1] for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0.

  2. First, notice that

    sn−sn+1=sn−sn3=sn(1−sn2).s_n - s_{n+1} = s_n - s_n^3 = s_n\p{1 - s_n^2}.sn​−sn+1​=sn​−sn3​=sn​(1−sn2​).

    By (1), we know that sn≥0s_n \geq 0sn​≥0, and because sn∈[0,1]s_n \in \br{0, 1}sn​∈[0,1], we also know that sn2≤1s_n^2 \leq 1sn2​≤1. Thus, 1−sn2≥01 - s_n^2 \geq 01−sn2​≥0, so sn−sn+1≥0s_n - s_{n+1} \geq 0sn​−sn+1​≥0 also, i.e., sn≥sn+1s_n \geq s_{n+1}sn​≥sn+1​, so sns_nsn​ is decreasing.

  3. By (1) and (2), we see that sns_nsn​ is a bounded monotone sequence, so it converges to some sss. Thus, by the limit laws, we can take limits on both sides of the recursive relation:

    sn+1=sn3  ⟹  s=s3  ⟹  s(1−s2)=0.s_{n+1} = s_n^3 \implies s = s^3 \implies s\p{1 - s^2} = 0.sn+1​=sn3​⟹s=s3⟹s(1−s2)=0.

    So, there are three possibilities: s∈{−1,0,1}s \in \set{-1, 0, 1}s∈{−1,0,1}. Since sn≥0s_n \geq 0sn​≥0 for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0, we get s≥0s \geq 0s≥0, so s≠−1s \neq -1s=−1. Because sns_nsn​ is decreasing, we also know that sn≤s0=12s_n \leq s_0 = \frac{1}{2}sn​≤s0​=21​, so s≤12s \leq \frac{1}{2}s≤21​ also. Thus, s=0s = 0s=0.

Subsequences

Definition

Let {sn}n≥m\set{s_n}_{n \geq m}{sn​}n≥m​ be a sequence. We say another sequence {tk}k≥1\set{t_k}_{k \geq 1}{tk​}k≥1​ is a subsequence of {sn}n≥m\set{s_n}_{n \geq m}{sn​}n≥m​ if there exist integers

m≤n1<n2<⋯m \leq n_1 < n_2 < \cdotsm≤n1​<n2​<⋯

such that tk=snkt_k = s_{n_k}tk​=snk​​.
Example 1.

If sn=(−1)ns_n = \p{-1}^nsn​=(−1)n, then s2k=1s_{2k} = 1s2k​=1 and s2k+1=−1s_{2k+1} = -1s2k+1​=−1.

Subsequences are similar to subsets, but with one important distinction: you have to respect the ordering of the original sequence. For example, if sn=ns_n = nsn​=n, then

1,3,2,4,5,…1, 3, 2, 4, 5, \ldots1,3,2,4,5,…

is not a subsequence of {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​.

Theorem (Bolzano-Weierstrass)

Every bounded sequence has a convergent subsequence.

This is a very important idea in analysis, but it's won't be particularly useful for us while we're looking at regular sequences.

Theorem

A sequence {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ converges if and only if every subsequence of {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ converges to the same limit.

This theorem is useful for us because it gives us another way to prove that sequence diverges. Instead of using the ε\epsilonε definition of a limit, we can just find two subsequences which converge to different numbers.

Example 2.

Let sn=(−1)n(1+1n)s_n = \p{-1}^n\p{1 + \frac{1}{n}}sn​=(−1)n(1+n1​). Notice that

s2k=1+12k→k→∞1ands2k+1=−(1+12k+1)→k→∞−1,s_{2k} = 1 + \frac{1}{2k} \xrightarrow{k\to\infty} 1 \quad\text{and}\quad s_{2k+1} = -\p{1 + \frac{1}{2k+1}} \xrightarrow{k\to\infty} -1,s2k​=1+2k1​k→∞​1ands2k+1​=−(1+2k+11​)k→∞​−1,

so {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ diverges.
Example 3.

Let sn=∣cos⁡nπ3∣s_n = \abs{\cos{\frac{n\pi}{3}}}sn​=∣∣​cos3nπ​∣∣​. Then

s3k=1ands3k+1=12,s_{3k} = 1 \quad\text{and}\quad s_{3k+1} = \frac{1}{2},s3k​=1ands3k+1​=21​,

so {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ must diverge.
Example 4.
(9.9)

This example will be helpful for one of the homework problems this week.

Suppose there exists N0N_0N0​ such that sn≤tns_n \leq t_nsn​≤tn​ for all n>N0n > N_0n>N0​.

  1. Prove that if lim⁡n→∞sn=∞\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \inftyn→∞lim​sn​=∞, then lim⁡n→∞tn=∞\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} t_n = \inftyn→∞lim​tn​=∞.
  2. Prove that if lim⁡n→∞sn\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_nn→∞lim​sn​ and lim⁡n→∞tn\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} t_nn→∞lim​tn​ exist, then lim⁡n→∞sn≤lim⁡n→∞tn\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n \leq \displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} t_nn→∞lim​sn​≤n→∞lim​tn​.
Solution.

  1. Let M>0M > 0M>0. Since lim⁡n→∞sn=∞\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \inftyn→∞lim​sn​=∞, there exists N1∈RN_1 \in \RN1​∈R such that if n>N1n > N_1n>N1​, then sn≥Ms_n \geq Msn​≥M. Thus, if n>max⁡ {N0,N1}n > \max\,\set{N_0, N_1}n>max{N0​,N1​}, we get

    M≤sn≤tn.M \leq s_n \leq t_n.M≤sn​≤tn​.

    Since MMM was arbitrary, this proves that lim⁡n→∞tn=∞\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} t_n = \inftyn→∞lim​tn​=∞ also.

  2. In Week 4, I proved a fact about non-negative sequences: if {an}n\set{a_n}_n{an​}n​ is a sequence such that an≥0a_n \geq 0an​≥0 for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0 and that lim⁡n→∞an\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} a_nn→∞lim​an​ exists, then lim⁡n→∞an≥0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} a_n \geq 0n→∞lim​an​≥0.

    If we set an=tn−sna_n = t_n - s_nan​=tn​−sn​, then an≥0a_n \geq 0an​≥0 (technically only for n>N0n > N_0n>N0​, but this doesn't make a big difference since we're working with limits), then because all the limits in question exist, the proposition and the limit laws tell us

    lim⁡n→∞tn−lim⁡n→∞sn=lim⁡n→∞(tn−sn)≥0  ⟹  lim⁡n→∞sn≤lim⁡n→∞tn.\lim_{n\to\infty} t_n - \lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \lim_{n\to\infty} \p{t_n - s_n} \geq 0 \implies \lim_{n\to\infty} s_n \leq \lim_{n\to\infty} t_n.n→∞lim​tn​−n→∞lim​sn​=n→∞lim​(tn​−sn​)≥0⟹n→∞lim​sn​≤n→∞lim​tn​.

    Alternatively, if we didn't have this theorem, we can also prove it using the ε\epsilonε definition directly. Let s=lim⁡n→∞sns = \displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_ns=n→∞lim​sn​ and t=lim⁡n→∞tnt = \displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} t_nt=n→∞lim​tn​, and suppose for the sake of contradiction that s>ts > ts>t.

    The idea is this: eventually, sns_nsn​ should be very close to sss, and tnt_ntn​ should be very close to ttt. If they're close enough, then we should eventually end up with sn>tns_n > t_nsn​>tn​, which contradicts our assumption that sn≤tns_n \leq t_nsn​≤tn​ for n>N0n > N_0n>N0​.

    Let ε=s−t2\epsilon = \frac{s - t}{2}ε=2s−t​, i.e., half the distance between sss and ttt. Since s=lim⁡n→∞sns = \displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_ns=n→∞lim​sn​, there exists N1∈RN_1 \in \RN1​∈R such that if n>N1n > N_1n>N1​, then

    ∣sn−s∣<ε  ⟹  sn−s>−ε  ⟹  sn>s−ε=s−(s−t2)=s+t2.\begin{aligned} \abs{s_n - s} < \epsilon &\implies s_n - s > - \epsilon \\ &\implies s_n > s - \epsilon = s - \p{\frac{s - t}{2}} = \frac{s + t}{2}. \end{aligned}∣sn​−s∣<ε​⟹sn​−s>−ε⟹sn​>s−ε=s−(2s−t​)=2s+t​.​

    Similarly, there exists N2∈RN_2 \in \RN2​∈R such that if n>N2n > N_2n>N2​, then

    ∣tn−t∣<ε  ⟹  tn−t<ε  ⟹  tn<t+ε=t+t−s2=s+t2.\begin{aligned} \abs{t_n - t} < \epsilon &\implies t_n - t < \epsilon \\ &\implies t_n < t + \epsilon = t + \frac{t - s}{2} = \frac{s + t}{2}. \end{aligned}∣tn​−t∣<ε​⟹tn​−t<ε⟹tn​<t+ε=t+2t−s​=2s+t​.​

    Thus, if n>max⁡ {N0,N1,N2}n > \max\,\set{N_0, N_1, N_2}n>max{N0​,N1​,N2​}, then

    tn<⏟n>N2s+t2<⏟n>N1sn≤⏟n>N0tnt_n \underbrace{<}_{n > N_2} \frac{s + t}{2} \underbrace{<}_{n > N_1} s_n \underbrace{\leq}_{n > N_0} t_ntn​n>N2​<​​2s+t​n>N1​<​​sn​n>N0​≤​​tn​

    which is a contradiction.
Example 5.
(basically 11.11)

Let SSS be a bounded set. Prove that there is a decreasing sequence {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ of points in SSS such that lim⁡n→∞sn=inf⁡S\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \inf{S}n→∞lim​sn​=infS.

First, if inf⁡S∈S\inf{S} \in SinfS∈S, then we can just set sn=inf⁡Ss_n = \inf{S}sn​=infS for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. Thus, from now on, we will assume that inf⁡S∉S\inf{S} \notin SinfS∈/S.

Our strategy will be to construct a sequence that satisfies two properties:

  1. sn≤inf⁡S+1ns_n \leq \inf{S} + \frac{1}{n}sn​≤infS+n1​.
  2. sn+1≤sns_{n+1} \leq s_nsn+1​≤sn​ for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0.

As before, (1) is here to make sure {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ actually converges to inf⁡S\inf{S}infS, and (2) is here to make sure the sequence is decreasing. We can do this by induction:

Base case: (n=1n = 1n=1)

Since inf⁡S\inf{S}infS is the greatest lower bound, this means that inf⁡S+1\inf{S} + 1infS+1 cannot be a lower bound. Thus, there exists s1∈Ss_1 \in Ss1​∈S such that s≤inf⁡S+1s \leq \inf{S} + 1s≤infS+1.

Inductive step:

Suppose we have s1,…,sn∈Ss_1, \ldots, s_n \in Ss1​,…,sn​∈S such that sk≤inf⁡S+1ks_k \leq \inf{S} + \frac{1}{k}sk​≤infS+k1​ for all 1≤k≤n1 \leq k \leq n1≤k≤n and so that s1≥s2≥⋯≥sns_1 \geq s_2 \geq \cdots \geq s_ns1​≥s2​≥⋯≥sn​. We need to find sn+1∈Ss_{n+1} \in Ssn+1​∈S such that sn+1≤inf⁡S+1n+1s_{n+1} \leq \inf{S} + \frac{1}{n+1}sn+1​≤infS+n+11​ and sn+1≤sns_{n+1} \leq s_nsn+1​≤sn​.

As before, we know that inf⁡S+1n+1\inf{S} + \frac{1}{n+1}infS+n+11​ cannot be a lower bound for SSS. Similarly, because inf⁡S∉S\inf{S} \notin SinfS∈/S, we get inf⁡S<sn\inf{S} < s_ninfS<sn​, so sns_nsn​ is not a lower bound for SSS either. Hence if we set ε=min⁡ {1n+1,sn−inf⁡S}\epsilon = \min\,\set{\frac{1}{n+1}, s_n - \inf{S}}ε=min{n+11​,sn​−infS}, then ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, so inf⁡S+ε\inf{S} + \epsiloninfS+ε is not a lower bound for SSS. By definition, there exists sn+1∈Ss_{n+1} \in Ssn+1​∈S such that sn+1≤inf⁡S+εs_{n+1} \leq \inf{S} + \epsilonsn+1​≤infS+ε. Thus,

ε≤1n+1  ⟹  sn+1≤inf⁡S+1n+1ε≤sn−inf⁡S  ⟹  sn+1≤inf⁡S+(sn−inf⁡S)=sn.\begin{aligned} \epsilon \leq \frac{1}{n+1} &\implies s_{n+1} \leq \inf{S} + \frac{1}{n+1} \\ \epsilon \leq s_n - \inf{S} &\implies s_{n+1} \leq \inf{S} + \p{s_n - \inf{S}} = s_n. \end{aligned}ε≤n+11​ε≤sn​−infS​⟹sn+1​≤infS+n+11​⟹sn+1​≤infS+(sn​−infS)=sn​.​

By induction, we have a decreasing sequence {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ of elements in SSS such that sn≤inf⁡S+1ns_n \leq \inf{S} + \frac{1}{n}sn​≤infS+n1​. Since inf⁡S\inf{S}infS is a lower bound for SSS, we have

inf⁡S≤sn≤inf⁡S+1n\inf{S} \leq s_n \leq \inf{S} + \frac{1}{n}infS≤sn​≤infS+n1​

for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. By the squeeze theorem, we get lim⁡n→∞sn=inf⁡S\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \inf{S}n→∞lim​sn​=infS.
